Born Joseph Alois Ratzinger in Marktl am Inn, Germany, youngest of three children to Joseph and Maria Ratzinger.
Ordained along with brother Georg Ratzinger in Freising.
Named archbishop of Munich and Freising.
Made a cardinal by Pope Paul VI.
Named prefect of the Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith by Pope John Paul II; takes up post in March 1982.
As dean of the College of Cardinals, Ratzinger presides over John Paul's funeral.
Elected 265th pope in one of the fastest conclaves in history.
Choosing name Benedict XVI, he says he is merely a simple, humble worker in the vineyard of the Lord.
First foreign trip, to World Youth Day in Cologne, Germany.
Meets with dissident theologian Hans Kung at papal summer residence.
First encyclical God is Love signed.
During trip to Poland, visits Auschwitz concentration camp.

During visit to Germany, delivers speech at University of Regensburg that enrages Muslims; quoting a Byzantine emperor who characterized some of the teachings of the Prophet Muhammad as evil and inhuman, particularly his command to spread by the sword the faith.
First volume of Jesus of Nazareth completed on his 80th birthday.
Signs letter to China's Catholics, urging them to unite under his authority.
Removes restrictions on celebrating the old Latin Mass in major gesture to traditional Catholics.
During visit to United States, prays for victims of Sept. 11, 2001 attacks at ground zero.
During visit to Australia for World Youth Day, meets with victims of priestly sex abuse and during a Mass apologizes for their suffering.
Lifts excommunication of Holocaust-denying Bishop Richard Williamson and three other ultra-traditionalist bishops of Society of St. Pius X, igniting outrage.
Acknowledges Vatican mistakes in Williamson affair, says Vatican must make better use of Internet to prevent future controversies.
En route to Cameroon, tells reporters aboard papal plane that condoms are not the solution to AIDS and can make problem worse, prompting widespread criticism.
During visit to the Holy Land, lays wreath at Yad Vashem memorial in Jerusalem, says Holocaust victims lost their lives but they will never lose their names.
Third encyclical Charity in Truth signed. Released July 7, 2009.
Breaks right wrist in late-night fall at summer vacation home.
Vatican announces pope is making it easier for Anglicans to convert en masse to Catholicism.
Rebukes Irish bishops for grave errors of judgment in handling clerical sex abuse but makes no mention of Vatican responsibility in letter to Irish faithful.
Orders major overhaul of Legion of Christ after Vatican investigation determines founder was a fraud.
During first state visit by a pope to Britain, meets with Queen Elizabeth II, Archbishop of Canterbury Rowan Williams and beatifies Anglican convert John Henry Newman.
Revises controversial condom-AIDS comments in book and says male prostitutes who use condoms may be taking a first step toward a more responsible sexuality.
Issues sweeping exoneration of Jews for the death of Christ in Jesus of Nazareth-Part II.
Beatifies John Paul II before 1.5 million people.
Tweets for the first time, announcing launch of Vatican news information portal.
Pope's former butler is convicted on charges he stole the pontiff's private letters and leaked them to a journalist.
Reveals in Latin that he is stepping down Feb. 28 during a meeting of Vatican cardinals, surprising even his closest collaborators.
Departs Vatican City in a helicopter bound for Castel Gandolfo, where he begins his final journey as a simple pilgrim.
Receives Pope Francis for lunch at Castel Gandolfo; the two men pray side-by-side and Francis insists We are brothers.
Joins Francis on altar to canonize St. John Paul II and St. John XXIII, the first time a reigning and retired pope celebrate Mass together.
In an essay, blames the clergy sex abuse scandal on the sexual revolution of the 1960s and an absence of God.
Contributes to a book reaffirming celibacy for priests at a time when Francis was considering an exception, sparking calls for rules governing future popes emeritus.
Travels to Germany to visit his ailing brother, the Rev. Georg Ratzinger, who dies two weeks later, on July 1.
Has his signature relaxation of restrictions on celebration of old Latin Mass reversed by Pope Francis.
Is faulted for his handling of four sex abuse cases while bishop of Munich in the 1970s and 1980s by independent report commissioned by German church.
Asks forgiveness for any grievous faults in handling of Munich priests, but denies personal or specific wrongdoing.
Pope Francis announces Benedict is very ill, asks for special prayers and visits him at his home.
Benedict dies at 9:34 a.m. at his home in the Vatican Gardens at age 95.
